notes.title: Eng→Pashto Translation: Techniques & Model Texts
notes.content: Handle dense literary/academic English: segment long sentences; keep metaphors culturally natural; preserve tense/aspect; mind izāfat/constructs. Practice on FPSC-style passages (criticism, biography, poetics, history).
keyTakeaways: Translate sense-for-sense first; refine for idiom/register.
Prefer standard Pashto orthography; avoid Urdu calques.
Build a personal glossary for recurrent academic terms.

notes.title: Pashto→English Translation: Fidelity with Fluency
notes.content: Preserve meaning and tone from classical/modern Pashto; unpack compressed imagery; translate culture-bound items with brief explicitation if needed (e.g., Pashtunwali terms).
keyTakeaways: Keep authorial voice; avoid over-literal word order.
Footnote or parenthetical gloss for key culture terms.
Consistent transliteration for names/places.

notes.title: Proverb Translation (Bidirectional) Strategy
notes.content: Identify the function (didactic, warning, wit). Choose: (i) Pashto→English: use closest natural English proverb; if none, literal + gloss. (ii) English→Pashto: prefer attested Pashto equivalent from reliable collections.
keyTakeaways: Don't force one-to-one; preserve pragmatic force.
Note regional variants; keep metric brevity.
Collect equivalence pairs for exam quick wins.

notes.title: Pashto Orthography & Bara Gali Decisions
notes.content: Use standard letters (e.g., ښ, ږ, ړ, ډ, ټ) and spacing; adopt Bara Gali/Academy recommendations for exams. Watch out for dialectal spellings.
keyTakeaways: Stick to standard forms in formal answers.
Retroflex/affricate letters change meaning—be precise.
Maintain consistent diacritics in examples/titles.

resources.title: Pashto Standard Orthography & Bara Gali Decisions

notes.title: Core Grammar for Translation
notes.content: Refresh verb system (simple vs compound, light verbs), ezāfat-like constructs, case/postpositions, participles, clitics; manage aspect and modality in literary prose.
keyTakeaways: Map English perfect/progressive to Pashto aspect accurately.
Mind enclitics and emphasis particles in rendering tone.
Keep consistent transliteration for grammar notes.

resources.title: David — Pashto and its Dialects: Descriptive Grammar

notes.title: Rahman Baba — Ethics & Mysticism in the Dīwān
notes.content: Anchor arguments with textual evidence on sincerity (ikhlāṣ), humility, love of God/man. Use authoritative editions and reliable translations.
keyTakeaways: Quote couplets with correct orthography & gloss.
Contrast with later Sufi voices for depth.
Show ethical universals with local color.

resources.title: Translation study of Rahman Baba (Paul Smith)

notes.title: Khushal Khan Khattak — Rāzmiyya & Cultural Codes
notes.content: Show the warrior-poet's blend of honor, freedom, counsel, realism. For 'razmiyya' essays, tie to history (Mughals, imprisonment) and close-read selected ghazals/qarīdas.
keyTakeaways: Balance biography with textual analysis.
Use couplets to evidence themes (honor, courage, counsel).
Cite modern scholarship for contemporary framing.

notes.title: Hamid Baba & Kazim Khan Shaida — Ghazal Features
notes.content: For Hamid Baba, emphasize delicacy of feeling (sōz-o-gudāz) and imagery; for Kazim Khan Shaida, trace themes, musicality and classical craft.
keyTakeaways: Select 3–5 couplets to illustrate hallmark features.
Contrast diction and metaphors with Rahman/Khushal.
Relate to Persianate ghazal conventions.

resources.title: Pashto Classics (general references)
resources.description: What exam expects re: classical poets

notes.title: Ghani Khan — Aesthetics, Existential Currents & Satire
notes.content: Discuss Khudi, beauty, freedom, humor; link to paintings and essays (The Pathan). Use recent papers for existential/Stylistic angles.
keyTakeaways: Blend poetic analysis with his philosophy and art.
Use satire examples; note romantic strain.
Reference English translations for Pashto→English tasks.

notes.title: Hamza Shinwari & Jafar Achakzai — Epistolary Debate (Man & God)
notes.content: Use the 1976 Quetta publication as context for modern philosophical exchange in Pashto letters.
keyTakeaways: Frame letters as literary-philosophical genre.
Extract positions on God/existence; compare styles.

notes.title: Prose, Drama & Short Story — Origins and Debates
notes.content: Discuss modern Pashto prose emergence, drama as a response to political climates, and short story's compact problem-focus.
keyTakeaways: Define 'afsanah' craft: compression, unity, effect.
Map drama's growth against sociopolitical shifts.
Cite early playwrights/novelists with examples.

notes.title: Roshaniyya Movement — Bayazid Ansari (Pīr Roshan)
notes.content: Cover origins, doctrine, literary output (Khayr al-Bayān), phases of movement, and its political-religious impact; relevance to tribal unification and Mughal opposition.
keyTakeaways: Tie movement to Pashto literary prose beginnings.
Use balanced sources; note controversies.
Connect to later Afridi/Orakzai resistance in Tirah.

resources.title: Pashto journal: Bayazid the first Pashto prose writer

notes.title: Akhund Darweza — Opposition & Prose (Makhzan-e-Islam, Noor Nama)
notes.content: Set up Darweza's critique of Roshaniyya; outline key works and prose style; note disciples and Darweza school writers (e.g., Akhun Salak).
keyTakeaways: Contrast theological stances with Pir Roshan.
Use excerpts to show prose features.
Cite manuscript history where relevant.

notes.title: Pashtun Origins & Identity Debates (Aryan vs. Israelite etc.)
notes.content: Survey competing origin theories and evidence (linguistic/anthropological/historical), and how these debates surface in Pashto essays.
keyTakeaways: Present multiple views with sources; avoid dogmatism.
Use linguistic/dialect evidence judiciously.
Relate to cultural identity and literature.

notes.title: Folklore Genres: Charbeta, Badala, Loba, Bagati, Allahu…
notes.content: Define forms, occasions, meters, and performance; use exemplars to illustrate function and aesthetics; link to proverb stock and identity.
keyTakeaways: Give clear definitions + examples for 2–3 forms.
Connect to oral tradition and communal memory.
Note regional performance differences.

notes.title: Pashto Criticism — Origins & Growth
notes.content: Outline the emergence of critical prose in Pashto, major critics, journals and university centers; methods borrowed from Urdu/Persian/English criticism.
keyTakeaways: Place Pashto criticism in South Asian context.
Name key journals (Academy/University outlets).
Cite representative essays/monographs.

notes.title: Pashto Dictionaries & Glossaries for Exam Work
notes.content: Use bilingual and monolingual dictionaries for precise lexical choices in translation and essay writing; build quick-access bookmark set.
keyTakeaways: Cross-check across two dictionaries to avoid false friends.
Prefer Academy/established projects for exam answers.
Keep a proverb/idiom mini-glossary.

notes.title: Proverbs as Cultural Molecules — Analysis Essays
notes.content: Support claims about identity/values with mataloona; show didactic, humorous, metaphorical functions; connect to folk narratives.
keyTakeaways: Quote proverb + provide succinct explication.
Use Academy collections and peer-reviewed articles.
Compare Pashto/English proverbs for translation tasks.

notes.title: Rowshani Movement in Tirah — Afterlives & Literature
notes.content: Trace followers (Afridi, Orakzai, etc.), Tirah freedom tradition, and literary echoes in later poetry/folklore.
keyTakeaways: Use multi-source corroboration for historical claims.
Connect movement politics to literary themes.
Reference specific ballads if possible.

notes.title: Pashto Folk Literature — Definition & Scope
notes.content: Define 'awlsi adab'; list core forms; illustrate with brief samples and social function.
keyTakeaways: Demonstrate oral→written transmission.
Tie forms to rites/occasions.
Use examples to show meter & refrain.

notes.title: Shēr Shāh Sūrī — Administrative/Military Reforms
notes.content: Summarize road/currency/land reforms and military re-organization; tie to Pashtun identity narratives in essays.
keyTakeaways: Use concise bullet points with dates.
Link to Pashtun statecraft themes in literature.

notes.title: Yunas Khalil & Abdul Rahim Majzoob — Modern Poetic Voices
notes.content: Discuss romantic and classical references (Greek allusions), language, and themes.
keyTakeaways: Cite poems with gloss; show mythological borrowing.
Contrast diction with earlier moderns.

notes.title: Translation Aids — Wordlists & Phrasebooks
notes.content: Build speed on collocations, set phrases, and everyday terms for narrative passages.
keyTakeaways: Maintain a live spreadsheet of tricky items.
Practice bidirectional paraphrasing.

notes.title: YouTube Lectures for Quick Revision (Selective)
notes.content: Use sparingly for conceptual refreshers; verify content against texts.
keyTakeaways: Prefer channels with textual citation or academic hosts.
Extract notes—not verbatim reliance.

notes.title: Idioms & Figures — Pashto↔English Translation Issues
notes.content: Identify idioms vs compositional phrases; choose strategy (equivalence, paraphrase, footnote).
keyTakeaways: Mark idioms during first pass; decide in revision.
Keep an idiom bank from past papers.

notes.title: Exam Strategy — What Repeats & How to Attempt
notes.content: Papers regularly test: Eng↔Pashto translation (14 marks each), proverb translation (6 marks), and 4× long essays (20 marks). Allocate time accordingly; use headings and quote lines accurately.
keyTakeaways: Attempt translation first while fresh; then essays.
For essays: outline → quote → analyze → conclude.
Keep couplet bank (fully vowelled if possible).

notes.title: Reference Sets for Pashto History & Movements
notes.content: Keep a 1-page timeline from Pir Roshan (1525–1585) to later successors, opposition by Akhund Darweza, and literary outputs.
keyTakeaways: Name works + genres + dates succinctly.
Note Tirah/Afridi/Orakzai connections.

notes.title: Quick Links — Syllabus & MCQs
notes.content: Use the official/reputed mirrors for syllabus and MCQ drilling when you need a break from long-form prep.
keyTakeaways: Syllabus sets study boundaries—keep it pinned.
MCQs help retain dates, firsts, and forms.
